body.value:
NOTE: This documentation is being updated for the new Kubernetes-based version of the Dramble!

Here’s the overall cluster architecture we’re targeting:

Once all the Pis are online and operational, you need to copy the included example.config.yml file to config.yml and modify it to suit your needs.

Next, run ansible-galaxy install -r playbooks/requirements.yml --force to install Ansible role dependencies.

Finally, run the Ansible playbook to provision the Raspberry Pis:

$ ansible-playbook -i inventory main.yml

After 5-10 minutes, you should see a summary of the completed tasks:

PLAY RECAP ****************************************************************
10.0.1.60               : ok=52   changed=29    unreachable=0    failed=0
10.0.1.61               : ok=136  changed=68    unreachable=0    failed=0
10.0.1.62               : ok=136  changed=68    unreachable=0    failed=0
10.0.1.63               : ok=58   changed=30    unreachable=0    failed=0
10.0.1.64               : ok=58   changed=30    unreachable=0    failed=0

At this point, all the software that will support your Drupal site is installed.

To un-provision a Pi, you can either use apt-get remove --purge [package] and apt-get autoremove to remove installed packages/configuration, then reboot… or you can reimage the microSD cards from a fresh copy of Raspbian Lite. I prefer the latter, but for quick testing/experimentation will do the former (or create Ansible playbooks to back out all the changes).

Raspberry Pi image used in architecture diagram by Multicherry, downloaded from Wikipedia. All other logos are copyright their respective owners.
body.processed:
NOTE: This documentation is being updated for the new Kubernetes-based version of the Dramble!

Here’s the overall cluster architecture we’re targeting:

Once all the Pis are online and operational, you need to copy the included example.config.yml file to config.yml and modify it to suit your needs.

Next, run ansible-galaxy install -r playbooks/requirements.yml --force to install Ansible role dependencies.

Finally, run the Ansible playbook to provision the Raspberry Pis:

$ ansible-playbook -i inventory main.yml

After 5-10 minutes, you should see a summary of the completed tasks:

PLAY RECAP ****************************************************************
10.0.1.60               : ok=52   changed=29    unreachable=0    failed=0
10.0.1.61               : ok=136  changed=68    unreachable=0    failed=0
10.0.1.62               : ok=136  changed=68    unreachable=0    failed=0
10.0.1.63               : ok=58   changed=30    unreachable=0    failed=0
10.0.1.64               : ok=58   changed=30    unreachable=0    failed=0

At this point, all the software that will support your Drupal site is installed.

To un-provision a Pi, you can either use apt-get remove --purge [package] and apt-get autoremove to remove installed packages/configuration, then reboot… or you can reimage the microSD cards from a fresh copy of Raspbian Lite. I prefer the latter, but for quick testing/experimentation will do the former (or create Ansible playbooks to back out all the changes).

Raspberry Pi image used in architecture diagram by Multicherry, downloaded from Wikipedia. All other logos are copyright their respective owners.
